Post_Title: This will teach Bangladesh a lesson for their actions. üáÆüá≥üí™
Comment_Text: On May 18, 2025, I came across the news that India has put new restrictions on imports from Bangladesh. The Indian government has now blocked the entry of goods worth around $770 million‚Äîalmost 42% of total imports from Bangladesh‚Äîthrough land ports. This decision came from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry, based on instructions from the Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT). Some of the major Bangladeshi products affected include ready-made garments, processed food, plastic products, cotton waste, and wooden furniture. For instance, garments from Bangladesh, which are worth about $618 million a year, can now only enter India through two seaports‚ÄîKolkata and Nhava Sheva in Mumbai. Previously, a large part of this trade happened through land routes, especially through West Bengal and the Northeastern states. Now, those land routes are closed for these goods. Another set of items worth about $153 million, such as flavored drinks and plastic items, are completely banned from being imported via land ports. To understand why India made this move, I looked into the background. Tensions between India and Bangladesh have been rising ever since a temporary government led by Muhammad Yunus took charge in Bangladesh. In recent months, Bangladesh has placed several restrictions on Indian exports. For example, since April 13, 2025, Bangladesh has not allowed yarn imports through land ports. Starting April 15, it also placed restrictions on rice imports from India through important border posts like Hili and Benapole. These trade barriers have frustrated India. Adding to this, Bangladesh has been getting closer to China and Pakistan, which has also annoyed Indian policymakers. This isn‚Äôt the first time India has responded to these shifts. Back on April 9, 2025, India withdrew a transshipment facility that it had granted Bangladesh in 2020. That facility had allowed Bangladesh to send goods to the Middle East and Europe through Indian ports and even via Delhi airport. Now, Bangladesh can no longer use that route. It has been limited to landlocked countries like Nepal and Bhutan. These new restrictions are likely to hit Bangladesh hard, especially its garment industry, which is a major part of the country‚Äôs economy. I found out that in 2023, Bangladesh exported $38 billion worth of garments globally, and $700 million of that went to India. What‚Äôs important is that 93% of these exports to India were made through land routes, which are now restricted. Because of this, exporters in Bangladesh may face higher costs and delays, which could hurt their business. Bangladesh is already the second-largest garment exporter in the world after China, and losing smooth access to the Indian market adds pressure. In terms of overall trade, India and Bangladesh had a total trade of $12.91 billion in FY24. Out of this, India exported $11.07 billion worth of goods to Bangladesh and imported $1.85 billion. This was a drop from the $14.24 billion total trade in 2022‚Äì23. The new restrictions could lower the trade volume even more and impact Bangladesh‚Äôs economy, which depends heavily on exporting to India. From India‚Äôs side, the move appears to be a way to hit back at Bangladesh for its recent trade restrictions and to protect local industries, especially textiles. India has made a few exceptions though. Products like fish, LPG, edible oils, and crushed stone are still allowed to enter through land ports. But overall, India seems to be sending a strong message that it is ready to adjust its trade policies to deal with both economic competition and changing geopolitical relationships. Bangladesh is a competitor in the textile market, and India may be trying to safeguard its own position. After looking at all this, it feels like India‚Äôs restrictions are not just about trade but also about asserting its influence in the region. By blocking goods worth $770 million from entering through land ports, India is clearly taking a tough stance. While it‚Äôs a move to protect its economy, it also reveals the growing tension between the two countries. If this continues, it could have lasting effects on trade and political relations in South Asia. For this type of more exclusive content and market updates daily 24*7 follow our WhatsApp channel we promise you will never be disappointed

Post_Title: This will teach Bangladesh a lesson for their actions. üáÆüá≥üí™
Comment_Text: Bangladeshi here. You guys scarce realize what a big L this is. Bangladesh exports about $70 billion a year. Exports to India stands at around 1 billion. Only about 1.5% of the total. Indian Import restrictions do not harm the economy and Indian demand is replacable with alternative international demands. India is a net exporter to Bangladesh, primarily in agricultural and livestock products, fertilizers and vehicles. While there's no inport restrictions on Indian goods, none of your exports to us are critical or non fungible. What this cost India is all the goodwill it had left. While Indians often like to pretend that everyone in Bangladesh is on Pakistan's side, or hates India, the reality on the ground is that a non insignificant portion of the population have a positive attitude towards India. Even after sacking the pro India Hasina regime, many would still argue for closer relations with India. But it's hard to argue for pivoting towards India when their government unilaterally, for no real reason, starts a trade war.

Comment_Text: You realise that this is not actual money which is lying in bank or cash but notional wealth. The stock markets fluctuate daily and many companies fluctuate wildly so are you going to do this calculation every day for every big shareholder against every other shareholder. Just to give another analogy. Mumbai is one of the most expensive real estate in the world and it keeps on going up and up every year. Just owning a 1-bhk will make you a crorepati. But do you actually see so many rich people around despite more than 70% families owning homes. So the point is there are differences between income, wealth, notional wealth, liquid wealth and such other concepts. Use them appropriately as per the context.

Post_Title: Ola...My first good profit on a stock
Comment_Text: I have been seeing people shitting on Ola since a few weeks before the IPO opened. Almost every post asking about the IPO was battered down by hoards of people saying the company has shitty fundamentals, shitty track record, shitty CEO, etc. People just don't like Bhavish Aggarwal in general, it seems. The first couple of days after listing was eerily silent on these subs, after everyone who shat on Ola saw their "technical analysis" down the drain. If we count both days as listing gains because any sane investor who believes in the company didn't sell, the IPO had already returned 44% by Tuesday. Now a couple of days of profit booking made these people come back screaming, as if they were personally invested in shorting Ola shares. People are stupidly comparing an EV manufacturer and now a lithium cell manufacturer, with service based startups like Zomato and PayTm and cosmetic retailers like Nykaa. They are even comparing an EV startup with other established ICE 2-wheeler manufacturers like Hero and TVS, to justify "loss making company". I guess people are just jealous of Bhavish or don't like his face. I think Ola is trying to grab hold of a couple of pretty lucrative sectors, such as EV and lithium cell manufacturing. With the entire world moving away from Chinese products, it's the right time for India to take that place. Ola is at least trying where it matters. P.S. - I haven't invested in this company so far, but it's on my watchlist.

Post_Title: I have found these shares with my parents name on them, can someone tell me what their value is now?
Comment_Text: The Registrar and Transfer Agent (RTA) for Reliance Industries Limited is **KFin Technologies Limited**. They handle all share-related matters, including transfer, dematerialization, dividend payments and issuing duplicate share certificates. ### Contact Details for KFin Technologies Limited: - **Address**: Selenium Building, Tower B, Plot No. 31 & 32, Financial District, Nanakramguda, Serilingampally Mandal, Hyderabad, Telangana ‚Äì 500 032, India. - **Telephone**: +91-40-67162222, +91-40-67161500 **Toll-Free No**: 1800-309-4001 - **Email**: rilinvestor @ kfintech.com einward.ris @ kfintech.com - **Website**: - The 3^rd share certificate of Reliance Communications Ventures Limited is no longer valid, since the company is delisted. - Go to > select "Reliance Industries Ltd > enter folio number to search unclaimed dividends - Contact Kfintech and ask them for unclaimed/pending/missing dividends and procedure to dematerialize physical share certificates into demat format. They will most likely ask for KYC documents and signature verification. Keep photocopies of all documents. You'll need to send physical share certificates for surrender to their Hyderabad office by courier or speed post.

Post_Title: I have found these shares with my parents name on them, can someone tell me what their value is now?
Comment_Text: The value is approximately INR 2.5 lakhs. You hold 36 shares of RIL from 2017, including 18 shares from the 2009 certificate and 9 shares before that. Based on this, you are also entitled to 76 shares of Jio Finance and 76 bonus RIL shares issued in October 2024, totaling a value of INR 2.5 lakhs. Please complete your KYC and get the missing shares duplicated before sending these to your broker for demat.

Post_Title: I have found these shares with my parents name on them, can someone tell me what their value is now?
Comment_Text: Your shares alongwith corporate action (bonus,split) post 2017+jio finance+unclaimed dividend might have been transferred to IEPF. First contact RTA and take details of unclaimed dividend and number of shares. Since the shares are in the name of your parents, make sure they have a demat account exactly in the same pattern as in shareholder, as the shares are returned by IEPF in demat account and submission of claim requires CML copy mandatorily. Then apply to IEPF, post that it generally takes 3-6 months for crediting back shares.
